Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Understanding Resettlement of Communities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: This Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement project will investigate how national policy changes shape the practices, strategies, and experiences of resettlement communities by conducting an analysis of how resettlement communities respond to the arrival of displaced people and communities. This study will contribute to scholarly research on theories about the relationship between humanitarianism, diversity, and community integration. The broader impacts of this research will 1) inform local resettlement policy, 2) inform local resettlement agencies’ initiatives and practices; and 3) provide insight into how local organizations, community members, and displaced people and communities experience resettlement. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this project will provide support to enable a promising student to establish an independent research career.<br/><br/>This study will address the following research questions: 1) how are local resettlement agencies impacted by changes in resettlement policies? 2) how are local-residents responding and reacting to resettlement, and 3) how do the experiences of displaced people and communities differ based on geographic location. To answer these questions, the PIs will use ethnographic and qualitative methods that include semi-structured interviews with resettlement agency employees, service providers, displaced people, and residents; focus groups; and participant observation. The results from this research project will provide new insights regarding resettlement programs and how resettlement is practiced and experienced in small and medium-sized cities, particularly as national perspectives on displaced people undergo rapid change.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This doctoral research examined how refugee resettlement takes place amid national changes to resettlement policies. The United States has historically resettled the majority of the world’s refugees, resettling over 3 million refugees since 1975; yet, over the past two decades, the refugee resettlement program has experienced significant changes, including a pause on refugee admissions at the beginning of the COVID-19 pandemic as well as iterations of a travel ban on refugees from certain countries. These admissions restrictions have been coupled with reductions to the annual refugee admissions ceiling. As a result of these changes and shifts in policies, local resettlement communities have had to adapt – or, in some cases, resettlement offices have closed. Given this context, this project investigated:

 

1.     How are local resettlement agencies navigating the shifting terrain of refugee policy and politics in the United States?

2.     How are local residents responding to refugee resettlement in this context, and to what extent do responses to refugee resettlement reflect and/or remake notions of humanitarianism, place, and belonging at the local scale? Are these dynamics shaped by race, racialization, and/or Islamophobia? 

3.     How do refugees navigate community integration at a time when the refugee program is viewed by some as a national security concern?

 

The research design adopted a case study approach to focus on resettlement in Missoula, Montana, one of the newest resettlement sites in the U.S. The NSF DDRI provided the financial support to conduct qualitative and ethnographic research over the course of 12 months in Missoula. This research included 50 in-depth interviews with a range of local actors, including refugees, resettlement staff, service providers, and volunteers; participant observation (occurring in places / at events such as city council meetings, resettlement agency consultations, community events, volunteer trainings, etc.); and an analysis of over 500 documents (e.g., newspaper articles, reports, briefings, newsletters, etc.). This data was analyzed thematically in accordance with the objectives of the research project.

 

Based on this research, the dissertation project demonstrates that local resettlement sites are not only contending with national changes to the resettlement program but are confronting a host of other challenges that shape resettlement services and experiences, including an acute housing crisis, the COVID-19 pandemic, and the in-migration of those seeking to live near Missoula’s natural amenities – a phenomenon that is further exacerbating local housing conditions. This project highlights the need to understand the local contexts that shape 1) how resettlement happens; and 2) how refugees themselves experience resettlement.

 

Scholars have long been examining refugee resettlement in the U.S. as well as internationally; yet, little has been written about how policies changes, the pandemic, and the ongoing housing crisis in the U.S. shape and impact refugee resettlement – both for those providing services and for those receiving services. This project furthers these academic discussions by demonstrating how local resettlement communities adapt to and are impacted by these national forces as well as the myriad ways local contexts shape this work and the resettlement experience for refugees.

 

The outcomes of this doctoral research are multiple. In terms of professional development for co-PI Fritzsche, she has designed and conducted a year-long study; presented at national conferences; professionally networked within the public and private sectors; and been invited to give research talks. At the time of writing this report, the co-PI is co-organizing a special issue for Geographical Review and submitting research papers for peer review to various journals in Geography and Refugee Studies.
